title: Full list: Bowlers with Test hat-tricks as Gus Atkinson joins elite company
description: Gus Atkinson became the 14th Englishman to claim a men's Test hat-trick on the second morning of the second New Zealand-England Test at Wellington.
author: Yas Rana
excerpt: Gus Atkinson became the 14th Englishman to claim a men's Test hat-trick on the second morning of the second New Zealand-England Test at Wellington. See the full list of Test hat-trick takers here.
text: Atkinson's hat-trick capped off an excellent England performance with the ball. The hosts resumed day two on 86-5, still trailing England by 194. It didn't take long for the tourists to make further inroads with Brydon Carse dismissing both Tom Blundell and Will O'Rourke in the fourth over of the morning. After brief resistance from Glenn Phillips and Nathan Smith, Atkinson brought about a dramatic end to the New Zealand innings, dismissing Smith, Matt Henry and Tim Southee in successive deliveries. Smith was dismissed leaving the ball, to a delivery that bounced more than he anticipated, cannoning off his gloves and into the stumps. Henry was outdone by a hostile bouncer that he could only fend to Ben Duckett at gully while Tim Southee was duped by a field that telegraphed another short ball but was instead lbw playing back to a fuller delivery. That left New Zealand all out for 125, 155 runs behind England's first innings total. The hat-trick was the 15th by an England bowler in a men's Test and the first since Moeen Ali claimed one against South Africa at the Kia Oval in 2017. In total, it's the 47th hat-trick in men's Test cricket. Full list of hat-tricks in men's Tests: Name Team Match Frederick Spofforth Australia vs England, Melbourne, 1878/79 Billy Bates England vs Australia, Melbourne, 1882/83 Johnny Briggs England vs Australia, Sydney, 1891/92 George Lohmann England vs South Africa, Port Elizabeth, 1895/96 Jack Hearne England vs Australia, Leeds, 1899 Hugh Trumble Australia vs England, Melbourne, 1901/02 Hugh Wes Hall West Indies vs Pakistan, Lahore, 1958/59 Geoff Griffin South Africa vs England, Lord's, 1960 Lance Gibbs West Indies vs Australia, Adelaide, 1960/61 Peter Petherick New Zealand vs Pakistan, Lahore, 1976/77 Courtney Walsh West Indies vs Australia, Brisbane, 1988/89 Merv Hughes Australia vs West Indies, Perth, 1988/89 Damien Fleming Australia vs Pakistan, Rawalpindi, 1994/95 Shane Warne Australia vs England, Melbourne, 1994/95 Dominic Cork England vs West Indies, Manchester, 1995 Darren Gough England vs Australia, Sydney, 1998/99 Wasim Akram Pakistan vs Sri Lanka, Lahore, 1998/99 Wasim Akram Pakistan vs Sri Lanka, Dhaka, 1998/99 Nuwan Zoysa Sri Lanka vs Zimbabwe, Bulawayo, 1999/2000 Abdul Razzaq Pakistan vs Sri Lanka, Galle, 1999/2000 Glenn McGrath Australia vs West Indies, Perth, 2000/01 Harbhajan Singh India vs Australia, Kolkata, 2000/01 Mohammad Sami Pakistan vs Sri Lanka, Lahore, 2001/02 Jermaine Lawson West Indies vs Australia, Barbados, 2002/03 Alok Kapali Bangladesh vs Pakistan, Peshawar, 2003 Andy Blignaut Zimbabwe vs Bangladesh, Harare, 2003/04 Matthew Hoggard England vs West Indies, Barbados, 2003/04 James Franklin New Zealand vs Bangladesh, Dhaka, 2004/05 Irfan Pathan India vs Pakistan, Karachi, 2005/06 Ryan Sidebottom England vs New Zealand, Hamilton, 2007/08 Peter Siddle Australia vs England, Brisbane, 2010/11 Stuart Broad England vs India, Nottingham, 2011 Sohag Gazi Bangladesh vs New Zealand, Chittagong, 2013/4 Stuart Broad England vs Sri Lanka, Leeds, 2014 Rangana Herath Sri Lanka vs Australia, Galle, 2016 Moeen Ali England vs South Africa, The Oval, 2017 Jasprit Bumrah India vs West Indies, Jamaica, 2019 Naseem Shah Pakistan vs Bangladesh, Rawalpindi, 2020 Keshav Maharaj South Africa vs West Indies, Saint Lucia, 2021 Gus html:
Atkinson's hat-trick capped off an excellent England performance with the ball. The hosts resumed day two on 86-5, still trailing England by 194.

It didn't take long for the tourists to make further inroads with Brydon Carse dismissing both Tom Blundell and Will O'Rourke in the fourth over of the morning.

After brief resistance from Glenn Phillips and Nathan Smith, Atkinson brought about a dramatic end to the New Zealand innings, dismissing Smith, Matt Henry and Tim Southee in successive deliveries.

Smith was dismissed leaving the ball, to a delivery that bounced more than he anticipated, cannoning off his gloves and into the stumps. Henry was outdone by a hostile bouncer that he could only fend to Ben Duckett at gully while Tim Southee was duped by a field that telegraphed another short ball but was instead lbw playing back to a fuller delivery.

That left New Zealand all out for 125, 155 runs behind England's first innings total.

The hat-trick was the 15th by an England bowler in a men's Test and the first since Moeen Ali claimed one against South Africa at the Kia Oval in 2017. In total, it's the 47th hat-trick in men's Test cricket.
